author: Agencies COTABATO
title: UN aid for Philippine Muslim farmers
text:
Agencies
COTABATO CITY
The United Nations is bringing in $470,000 worth of agriculture support to Muslim farmers affected over the years by armed conflict and natural calamities in the Philippines' Central Mindanao area.
The country representative of the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (UN-FAO) said the aid was part of the $2.7 million five-year support programme started in 2011 with the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (ARMM).
The final phase of the UN-FAO aid was covered by a memorandum of agreement signed between UN-FAO country representative Jose Luis Fernandez and ARMM Agriculture Secretary Makmod Mending, Jr.
Following the signing, the UN-FAO will deliver rice, corn and vegetable seeds, as well as bags of fertiliser, and hand tools to 930 rice farmers and 2,710 corn tillers in 16 Maguindanao towns. A proportionate share had been allocated for 480 and 880 rice and corn farmers in Pikit town in nearby North Cotabato province.
Both officials considered the assistance package timely, as the region's mainly agricultural economy was severely affected by massive community displacement due to armed conflict, and the recent dry-spell and floods that hit Maguindanao, ARMM's top agriculture-producing province.
"The intervention is a follow through to a continuing commitment to help communities affected by the conflict in the Southern Philippines," said Fernandez.
The UN agency official foresaw"a more strengthened collaboration," adding he hoped"to be back soon to see the light of dawn enjoyed by all."
